cleaned = cleanBase64(input);\n \n if (!isValidBase64(cleaned)) {\n throw new Error('Invalid Base64 string');\n }\n \n try {\n return atob(cleaned);\n } catch (error) {\n throw new Error(\`Decoding failed: \${error.message}\`);\n }\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n## Conclusion\n\nMost Base64 errors stem from invalid characters, encoding mismatches, or improper handling of binary data. Use validation functions, handle Unicode properly, and test your encoding/decoding pipeline thoroughly to avoid these common pitfalls.` }, { id: 9, title: "Base64 in API Development: Best Practices", category: "base64", excerpt: "Learn how to effectively use Base64 encoding in API development with security and performance best practices.", keywords: ["base64 encoding", "encode to base64", "base64 decode online"], readTime: "10 min read", date: "2026-01-06", content: `# Base64 in API Development: Best Practices\n\nBase64 encoding is essential in API development for handling binary data. This guide covers best practices for secure and efficient implementation.\n\n## Base64 in Authentication\n\n### Basic HTTP Authentication\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Client-side: Encoding credentials\nfunction createBasicAuthHeader(username, password) {\n const credentials = \`\${username}:\${password}\`;\n const encoded = btoa(credentials);\n return \`Basic \${encoded}\`;\n}\n\n// Usage\nconst authHeader = createBasicAuthHeader('user', 'pass');\nfetch('/api/data', {\n headers: {\n 'Authorization': authHeader\n }\n});\n\`\`\`\n\n### Server-side Validation\n\`\`\`python\n# Python/FastAPI example\nimport base64\nfrom fastapi import HTTPException, Depends\nfrom fastapi.security import HTTPBasic, HTTPBasicCredentials\n\nsecurity = HTTPBasic()\n\ndef validate_credentials(credentials: HTTPBasicCredentials = Depends(security)):\n # Credentials are automatically decoded by FastAPI\n if credentials.username == "user" and credentials.password == "pass":\n return credentials\n raise HTTPException(status_code=401, detail="Invalid credentials")\n\`\`\`\n\n### Security Considerations\n\n⚠️ **Important**: Basic Auth with Base64 is NOT secure over HTTP!\n\n\`\`\`javascript\n// ❌ Never do this over HTTP\nfetch('http://api.example.com/data', {\n headers: {\n 'Authorization': 'Basic dXNlcjpwYXNz' // Easily decoded!\n }\n});\n\n// ✅ Always use HTTPS\nfetch('https://api.example.com/data', {\n headers: {\n 'Authorization': 'Basic dXNlcjpwYXNz'\n }\n});\n\`\`\`\n\n## Binary Data in APIs\n\n### Sending Files via JSON\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Convert file to Base64 for JSON transmission\nfunction fileToBase64(file) {\n return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {\n const reader = new FileReader();\n reader.onload = () => {\n // Remove data URL prefix\n const base64 = reader.result.split(',')[1];\n resolve(base64);\n };\n reader.onerror = reject;\n reader.readAsDataURL(file);\n });\n}\n\n// API request with file\nasync function uploadFile(file) {\n const base64Data = await fileToBase64(file);\n \n const response = await fetch('/api/upload', {\n method: 'POST',\n headers: {\n 'Content-Type': 'application/json'\n },\n body: JSON.stringify({\n filename: file.name,\n content: base64Data,\n mimeType: file.type\n })\n });\n \n return response.json();\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n### Server-side File Handling\n\`\`\`python\n# FastAPI example for receiving Base64 files\nfrom fastapi import FastAPI, HTTPException\nfrom pydantic import BaseModel\nimport base64\nimport os\n\nclass FileUpload(BaseModel):\n filename: str\n content: str # Base64 encoded\n mimeType: str\n\n@app.post("/api/upload")\nasync def upload_file(file_data: FileUpload):\n try:\n # Decode Base64 content\n file_content = base64.b64decode(file_data.content)\n \n # Save file\n file_path = f"uploads/{file_data.filename}"\n with open(file_path, "wb") as f:\n f.write(file_content)\n \n return {\n "success": True,\n "filename": file_data.filename,\n "size": len(file_content)\n }\n except Exception as e:\n raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail=f"Upload failed: {str(e)}")\n\`\`\`\n\n## JWT Token Handling\n\n### JWT Structure with Base64\n\`\`\`javascript\n// JWT consists of three Base64-encoded parts\nconst jwt = "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzdWIiOiIxMjM0NTY3ODkwIiwibmFtZSI6IkpvaG4gRG9lIiwiaWF0IjoxNTE2MjM5MDIyfQ.SflKxwRJSMeKKF2QT4fwpMeJf36POk6yJV_adQssw5c";\n\n// Decode JWT parts (for inspection only - don't trust without verification!)\nfunction decodeJWT(token) {\n const parts = token.split('.');\n \n if (parts.length !== 3) {\n throw new Error('Invalid JWT format');\n }\n \n return {\n header: JSON.parse(atob(parts[0])),\n payload: JSON.parse(atob(parts[1])),\n signature: parts[2] // Don't decode signature\n };\n}\n\n// Usage\ntry {\n const decoded = decodeJWT(jwt);\n console.log('Header:', decoded.header);\n console.log('Payload:', decoded.payload);\n} catch (error) {\n console.error('Invalid JWT:', error.message);\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n### URL-Safe Base64 for JWTs\n\`\`\`javascript\n// JWT uses URL-safe Base64 (no padding, different characters)\nfunction base64UrlEncode(str) {\n return btoa(str)\n .replace(/\\+/g, '-')\n .replace(/\\//g, '_')\n .replace(/=/g, '');\n}\n\nfunction base64UrlDecode(str) {\n // Add padding if needed\n str += '='.repeat((4 - str.length % 4) % 4);\n \n // Replace URL-safe characters\n str = str.replace(/-/g, '+').replace(/_/g, '/');\n \n return atob(str);\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n## Data URIs in APIs\n\n### Embedding Images in JSON\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Create data URI from Base64\nfunction createDataURI(base64Data, mimeType) {\n return \`data:\${mimeType};base64,\${base64Data}\`;\n}\n\n// API response with embedded image\nconst apiResponse = {\n user: {\n id: 123,\n name: "John Doe",\n avatar: createDataURI(base64ImageData, "image/jpeg")\n }\n};\n\n// Client-side usage\nconst img = document.createElement('img');\nimg.src = apiResponse.user.avatar; // Direct usage\n\`\`\`\n\n### Optimizing Data URIs\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Check if Base64 is efficient for the use case\nfunction shouldUseDataURI(fileSize, requestFrequency) {\n // Rules of thumb:\n // - Small files (< 10KB): Often beneficial\n // - Frequently requested: Use separate endpoint\n // - One-time use: Data URI might be good\n \n if (fileSize > 10 * 1024) { // 10KB\n return false; // Too large for embedding\n }\n \n if (requestFrequency === 'high') {\n return false; // Use caching with separate endpoint\n }\n \n return true;\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n## Best Practices\n\n### 1. Size Limitations\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Set reasonable limits for Base64 data\nconst MAX_BASE64_SIZE = 5 * 1024 * 1024; // 5MB\n\nfunction validateBase64Size(base64String) {\n const sizeInBytes = (base64String.length * 3) / 4;\n \n if (sizeInBytes > MAX_BASE64_SIZE) {\n throw new Error(\`File too large: \${sizeInBytes} bytes (max: \${MAX_BASE64_SIZE})\`);\n }\n \n return true;\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n### 2. Input Validation\n\`\`\`python\n# Server-side validation\nimport re\n\ndef validate_base64(data: str) -> bool:\n # Check format\n base64_pattern = re.compile(r'^[A-Za-z0-9+/]*={0,2}$')\n if not base64_pattern.match(data):\n return False\n \n # Check if decodable\n try:\n base64.b64decode(data, validate=True)\n return True\n except Exception:\n return False\n\n# Usage in API endpoint\n@app.post("/api/data")\nasync def process_data(data: dict):\n if 'content' in data:\n if not validate_base64(data['content']):\n raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Invalid Base64 data")\n \n # Process valid data...\n\`\`\`\n\n### 3. Error Handling\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Robust Base64 processing\nclass Base64Handler {\n static encode(data) {\n try {\n if (typeof data !== 'string') {\n throw new Error('Input must be a string');\n }\n return btoa(data);\n } catch (error) {\n throw new Error(\`Encoding failed: \${error.message}\`);\n }\n }\n \n static decode(data) {\n try {\n if (!data || typeof data !== 'string') {\n throw new Error('Invalid input for decoding');\n }\n \n // Clean the input\n const cleaned = data.replace(/\\s/g, '');\n \n return atob(cleaned);\n } catch (error) {\n throw new Error(\`Decoding failed: \${error.message}\`);\n }\n }\n \n static isValid(data) {\n try {\n this.decode(data);\n return true;\n } catch {\n return false;\n }\n }\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n### 4. Performance Optimization\n\n#### Compression Before Encoding\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Compress data before Base64 encoding\nasync function compressAndEncode(data) {\n // Use compression API if available\n if ('CompressionStream' in window) {\n const stream = new CompressionStream('gzip');\n const writer = stream.writable.getWriter();\n const reader = stream.readable.getReader();\n \n writer.write(new TextEncoder().encode(data));\n writer.close();\n \n const chunks = [];\n let done = false;\n \n while (!done) {\n const { value, done: readerDone } = await reader.read();\n done = readerDone;\n if (value) chunks.push(value);\n }\n \n const compressed = new Uint8Array(chunks.reduce((acc, chunk) => acc + chunk.length, 0));\n let offset = 0;\n for (const chunk of chunks) {\n compressed.set(chunk, offset);\n offset += chunk.length;\n }\n \n // Convert to Base64\n return btoa(String.fromCharCode(...compressed));\n }\n \n // Fallback: direct encoding\n return btoa(data);\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n#### Streaming for Large Data\n\`\`\`javascript\n// Stream large Base64 data\nfunction* streamBase64Decode(base64String, chunkSize = 1024) {\n for (let i = 0; i < base64String.length; i += chunkSize) {\n const chunk = base64String.slice(i, i + chunkSize);\n yield atob(chunk);\n }\n}\n\n// Usage\nfor (const chunk of streamBase64Decode(largeBase64String)) {\n // Process chunk\n processChunk(chunk);\n}\n\`\`\`\n\n### 5. Documentation\n\n\`\`\`yaml\n# OpenAPI/Swagger documentation example\npaths:\n /api/upload:\n post:\n summary: Upload file as Base64\n requestBody:\n required: true\n content:\n application/json:\n schema:\n type: object\n properties:\n filename:\n type: string\n example: "document.pdf"\n content:\n type: string\n format: base64\n description: "File content encoded in Base64"\n maxLength: 5242880 # 5MB in Base64\n mimeType:\n type: string\n example: "application/pdf"\n required:\n - filename\n - content\n - mimeType\n\`\`\`\n\n## Security Checklist\n\n- [ ] Always use HTTPS for Base64-encoded sensitive data\n- [ ] Validate Base64 input on server-side\n- [ ] Set appropriate size limits\n- [ ] Don't use Base64 for passwords (use proper hashing)\n- [ ] Sanitize file names and types\n- [ ] Implement rate limiting for upload endpoints\n- [ ] Log security-relevant events\n\n## Conclusion\n\nBase64 is a powerful tool in API development when used correctly. Focus on security, validation, and performance optimization. Always remember that Base64 is encoding, not encryption, and should be used over secure connections for sensitive data.` }]; const categories = [{ id: 'all', name: 'All Posts', count: blogPosts.length import React, { useState } from 'react'; const BlogSection = ({ onNavigate }) => { const [selectedCategory, setSelectedCategory] = useState('all'); const [selectedPost, setSelectedPost] = useState(null); // Blog posts data based on the content file const blogPosts = [ // Base64 Tool Posts { id: 1, title: "How to Encode and Decode Base64: A Complete Developer's Guide", category: "base64", excerpt: "Learn everything about Base64 encoding and decoding with practical examples in JavaScript, Python, PHP, and Java.", keywords: ["base64 encode", "base64 decode", "base64 encoder online"], readTime: "8 min read", date: "2026-01-15", content: ` # How to Encode and Decode Base64: A Complete Developer's Guide Base64 encoding is a fundamental concept every developer should understand. This comprehensive guide covers everything you need to know about Base64 encoding and decoding. ## What is Base64? Base64 is a binary-to-text encoding scheme that represents binary data in an ASCII string format. It's commonly used in web development, APIs, and data transmission. ## Why Use Base64? - **Data Transmission**: Safely transmit binary data over text-based protocols - **Web APIs**: Encode binary data in JSON responses - **Authentication**: Basic HTTP authentication uses Base64 - **Data URIs**: Embed images and files directly in HTML/CSS ## How Base64 Works Base64 uses 64 characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, and /. It converts every 3 bytes of binary data into 4 ASCII characters. ## Code Examples ### JavaScript \`\`\`javascript // Encoding const encoded = btoa("Hello World"); console.log(encoded); // SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ= // Decoding const decoded = atob(encoded); console.log(decoded); // Hello World \`\`\` ### Python \`\`\`python import base64 # Encoding encoded = base64.b64encode(b"Hello World").decode('utf-8') print(encoded) # SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ= # Decoding decoded = base64.b64decode(encoded).decode('utf-8') print(decoded) # Hello World \`\`\` ## Best Practices 1. Always validate Base64 strings before decoding 2. Use URL-safe Base64 for URLs and filenames 3. Consider compression before encoding large data 4. Handle encoding errors gracefully ## Conclusion Base64 is an essential tool for web developers. Understanding its proper usage will help you build more robust applications. ` }, { id: 2, title: "Base64 Encoding Explained: When and Why to Use It", category: "base64", excerpt: "Understand the practical applications of Base64 encoding in modern web development and when to use it effectively.", keywords: ["base64 encoding", "base64 string converter", "encode to base64"], readTime: "6 min read", date: "2026-01-12", content: ` # Base64 Encoding Explained: When and Why to Use It Base64 encoding serves specific purposes in web development. Let's explore when and why you should use it. ## Understanding Base64 Base64 was created to solve the problem of transmitting binary data over text-based protocols that were designed for ASCII text. ## When to Use Base64 ### HTTP Authentication Basic HTTP authentication uses Base64 to encode credentials: \`\`\` Authorization: Basic dXNlcm5hbWU6cGFzc3dvcmQ= \`\`\` ### Data URIs Embed images directly in HTML/CSS: \`\`\`html \`\`\` ### API Responses Include binary data in JSON: \`\`\`json { "filename": "document.pdf", "content": "JVBERi0xLjQKJcOkw7zDtsO..." } \`\`\` ## Base64 vs Encryption **Important**: Base64 is NOT encryption! It's encoding for data transmission, not security. ## Performance Considerations - Base64 increases data size by ~33% - Consider compression before encoding - Use streaming for large files ## Common Mistakes 1. Using Base64 for security (it's not secure!) 2. Not handling padding correctly 3. Forgetting URL-safe variants for URLs ## Conclusion Use Base64 for data transmission, not security. It's perfect for APIs, data URIs, and protocol compatibility. ` }, // Code Diff Tool Posts { id: 3, title: "Code Diff Tools: The Ultimate Guide for Developers", category: "diff", excerpt: "Master code comparison with this comprehensive guide to diff tools, from basic usage to advanced techniques.", keywords: ["code diff tool", "compare code online", "text diff tool"], readTime: "10 min read", date: "2026-01-10", content: ` # Code Diff Tools: The Ultimate Guide for Developers Code diff tools are essential for every developer's toolkit. This guide covers everything from basic usage to advanced techniques. ## What is a Code Diff Tool? A diff tool compares two pieces of text or code and highlights the differences between them. It's invaluable for: - Code reviews - Debugging changes - Merging code - Version control ## Types of Diff Tools ### Command Line Tools - \`diff\` (Unix/Linux) - \`git diff\` (Git) - \`fc\` (Windows) ### GUI Tools - Beyond Compare - WinMerge - Meld ### Online Tools - Our Code Diff Tool - Diffchecker - Text-compare ## How to Use Diff Tools ### Basic Usage 1. Paste your original code in the left panel 2. Paste your modified code in the right panel 3. Click "Compare" to see differences ### Understanding Output - **Green lines**: Added content - **Red lines**: Removed content - **Yellow lines**: Modified content - **Gray lines**: Unchanged context ## Advanced Features ### Ignore Whitespace Useful when comparing code with different formatting: \`\`\`javascript // These would be considered identical with whitespace ignored function hello(){return "world";} function hello() { return "world"; } \`\`\` ### Context Lines Control how many unchanged lines to show around changes for better context. ## Best Practices 1. **Use meaningful commit messages** when using with version control 2. **Review changes carefully** before merging 3. **Use side-by-side view** for better visualization 4. **Ignore whitespace** when formatting doesn't matter ## Troubleshooting Common Issues ### Large Files - Use streaming diff tools - Consider splitting large files - Use binary diff for non-text files ### Encoding Issues - Ensure both files use the same encoding - Convert to UTF-8 when possible ## Conclusion Mastering diff tools will make you a more efficient developer. Practice with different types of changes to become proficient. ` }, // Regex Tool Posts { id: 4, title: "Regex Tester Tutorial: Master Regular Expressions", category: "regex", excerpt: "Learn how to test and debug regular expressions effectively with practical examples and best practices.", keywords: ["regex tester", "regular expression tester", "regex101"], readTime: "12 min read", date: "2026-01-08", content: ` # Regex Tester Tutorial: Master Regular Expressions Regular expressions are powerful tools for pattern matching and text processing. This tutorial will help you master regex testing. ## What is Regex? Regular expressions (regex) are sequences of characters that define search patterns. They're used for: - Input validation - Text processing - Data extraction - Search and replace operations ## Why Use Regex Testers?
